subject: Re: [junit] Runtime arguments to be submitted to MyTestCase
msgSnippet: You want to be able to share variables without using static.  There s an easy way to do this using JUnit, but you lose out on dynamic suite generation
messageBody:
You want to be able to share variables without using static. There's an
easy way to do this using JUnit, but you lose out on dynamic suite
generation unfortunately.

import junit.framework.*;
/**
* Accepts arguments at runtime
**/
public class RuntimeArgumentsTest extends TestCase {

private final String[] args;

public RuntimeArgumentsTest(String[] args, String name) {
super(name);
this.args = args;
}

public void testStuff() {
assertNotNull(args);
assertEquals(args[0], "hi");
}

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
String[] args = new String[] { "bye" };
suite.addTest(new RuntimeArguments(args, "testStuff")); // this
will fail
args = new String[] { "hi" };
suite.addTest(new RuntimeArguments(args, "testStuff")); // this
will pass
return suite;
}
}

Hope that helps. There's got to be a way we can keep this behavior
without losing the ability to dynamically generate the suite, right?

Regarding the license, JUnit is actually using the IBM Common Public
License. If it were using the GPL, however, you only have to publish
your changes if you distribute the binary. If you're only using JUnit
for in house testing--and you don't distribute it--you don't *have* to
distribute your changes (though it is a nice act, if they're not totally
specific to your project).

-shane
